Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our new paper to appear at GECC=
O, "On the Deleterious Effects of A Priori Objectives on Evolution and Repr=
esentation."  You can get it here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_=
gecco11.pdf

Abstract: 
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/woolley.g=
ecco11.html

As some of you have been following through our articles on nov=
elty search and my keynote talk on "Searching Without Objectives," our rese=
arch group has been questioning the role of objectives in evolution and mac=
hine learning.  However, much of this focus has been on exploring alternati=
ve paradigms such as novelty search.  In contrast, this new paper aims to e=
xpose directly some of the most serious problems with objective-based searc=
h itself, both practically and philosophically.

The message is not only th=
at objectives may not be the best way to drive evolution.  Perhaps deeper t=
han that, the results suggest that the usual way we evaluate our algorithms=
, i.e. by giving them a task and seeing how reliably they can solve it, may=
 be flawed in the sense that it may not actually be accurately measuring th=
e real potential of such algorithms.  We probably should rethink whether de=
manding the same result over and over again with 100% reliability is really=
 a good way to ascertain the potential an evolutionary algorithm.  The pape=
r gives the full story.

ken
